Authors:
Thomas Lecocq, Denis Michez, Alexandre Dewulf, Pierre
Rasmont, Simon Dellicour
Title:
Three in one: integrative taxonomy of the red-tailed
bumblebee species complex Bombus lapidarius (L.) (Hymenoptera,
Apidae)
Journal: Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society
Keywords:
Integrative taxonomy  species delimitation  subspecies 
Bombus
Abstract:
The systematic is a challenging topic for biologists. Many
morphological, molecular or chemical methods have been used to address
the question of species taxonomic status. However, all of these methods
have their own limits. The next step for progressing in systematics is
to consider both multiple evidences to evaluate the taxonomic status.
The integrative taxonomy aims to overcome the limitations of each
approach by corroboration of independent evidences. However, the
identification of taxa defined by molecular and chemical characters is
not within easy reach of all biologists and amateur collectors. Here, we
apply an integrative taxonomic approach to the confused and doubtful
red-tailed bumblebee complex (Bombus lapidarius) prior to determine a
posteriori morphological pragmatic identification characters. We set up
an integrative decision framework on the basis of (i) three independent
genes (two nuclear and one mitochondrial) and (ii) cephalic labial gland
secretions, an eco-chemical trait used in bumblebee species
discrimination. We investigate the wing shape and the colour pattern as
morphological pragmatic identification characters. Our results show that
B. lapidarius gather three species B. caucasicus (resurrected species
status), B. bisiculus sp. nov., and B. lapidarius. We establish the
suitability of the colour pattern as pragmatic identification characters
for these species.
